Appendix 1- Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
To set out the process of requesting echocardiograms and the staff which may request them as follows:
Inpatient Echocardiograms=IPEs;
Outpatient Echocardiograms=OPEs.
To prevent inappropriate requests for echocardiograms in order to reduce the waiting time and to avoid delay of patient treatment and/or discharge.
To maximise the efficiency of the echocardiography service.
Equality Impact Assessment

MEHT is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. In accordance with this, the echocardiogram guidelines are based on clinical factors and will not be affected by race and ethnic origin, disability, gender, culture, religion or belief, sexual orientation or age.
(Refer to Appendix A)
Scope
IPEs and OPEs will be performed by:
Qualified cardiac physiologist with proven training in echo;
Student cardiac physiologist under supervision of a qualified cardiac physiologist.

In some circumstances the IPE may be performed by a physician who is trained in echocardiography under the supervision of a qualified cardiac physiologist or by a physician specialising in cardiology who has echocardiography experience.
Infection Prevention/Control

All staff performing OPEs and IPEs will follow the Trusts Hand Hygiene Policy. The echo probe will be cleaned after each use with a suitable disinfectant wipe. All equipment which has come into contact with the patient will be cleaned in line with trust infection control policies and guidelines.
Staff and Training
Training regarding the requesting of OPEs/IPEs will be provided via distribution of this policy.
The Cardiac team are aware of the referral guidelines for this test. It will be their responsibility to ensure their staff are aware of the guidelines.
Emergency Requests

An emergency IPE may be useful in the management of patients in specific circumstances (see section 8). In such cases it is best to contact a cardiology registrar and/or visit the cardiac department to personally request the echo study. The physiologist using the portable echo machine also has an emergency bleep. The number can be obtained from the cardiac department in emergency situations only.
Considerations for Requesting an Echocardiogram
Firstly check that an echocardiogram has not recently been performed. If the report cannot be located in the patient notes it can be accessed via TOMCAT or from the cardiac department.

Ensure that the reason for the request is clearly stated and include all relevant clinical details. All requests will be screened. Ambiguous requests or those which fall outside the accepted guidelines will be returned.

Remember practicalities. Body habitus (physique type), significant respiratory disease and heart rates 100bpm make transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) technically difficult. This may result in an inconclusive study.
All request forms must be completed fully with Consultant name, requesting Doctors name and bleep number.

Requests from A&E will not generally be accepted unless they fall within the ‘emergency requests' category described in section 6. Patients are only on these wards for a short period of time and have usually been moved or discharged before the echo can be performed. It is usually better for an echo to be requested once the patient has been admitted to a ward and is therefore under the care of a Consultant. If the indication for IPE does not fall within the emergency category but is still required it is best to consult a cardiology registrar.
IPEs should not be used for monitoring chronic conditions or where the data obtained has no immediate impact on patient management.
Inpatient Echocardiogram Triage
Grade 1 (Emergency Echo) Echocardiography to be done immediately:
Likely acute pericardial tamponade;
Likely acute pulmonary embolism to inform a decision regarding thrombolysis;
As directed by Cardiologist.
Grade 2 (Within 24 hours)
Results likely to change immediate patient management and to be done within 24 hours. Priority within that time to be discussed with the Cardiac Department and/or Cardiology doctors:

Detection of high-risk complications of infective endocarditis where patient is haemodynamically unstable. Two sets of positive blood cultures and/or new murmur. Individual cases to be discussed with Cardiac Department;
Murmur following acute or recent MI (Myocardial Infarction) where papillary muscle rupture or ventricular septal rupture is suspected;
Persistent hypotension of unknown cause where patient is haemodynamically unstable and not responding to intensive care;
Suspected pericardial effusion/pericardial tamponade or bleeding following chest trauma;
Suspected aortic dissection (including following possible deceleration injury).
Grade 3

8.3.1 Echocardiography is indicated but may not change immediate management. Echo should be performed as an in-patient if possible and maybe performed as an outpatient following discussion with referring doctor.
8.3.2 All other echocardiography requests not mentioned in grades 1 and
Indications for the use of echocardiography in the Inpatient setting (Grade 3)
Heart Murmur
Indicated:
Murmur in the presence of acute Cardiac/respiratory compromise;
Murmur in an asymptomatic patient in whom clinical findings suggest acute structural heart disease (Have not had an echocardiogram in the last 12 months).
Not Indicated:
A Patient with known heart murmur who is asymptomatic with no change in their clinical status;
Incidental finding of a new murmur.
Valvular disease
Indicated:
Initial assessment of aetiology, severity, ventricular size and function in symptomatic/haemodynamically unstable patients;
Repeat assessment of valvular pathology with acute change in patients clinical status.
Not Indicated
Asymptomatic patient with known valvular pathology with no change in their acute clinical status;
Routine assessment in an asymptomatic/haemodynamically presenting with new murmur.
Prosthetic valve assessment
Indicated:
Repeat assessment of prosthetic valve with acute change in patient's clinical status;
Repeat assessment of prosthetic valve following exposure to clinical risk of valve thrombus.
Not Indicated:
Repeat assessment of an asymptomatic patient who has previously had a prosthetic valve;
Repeat assessment of patients whose clinical status precludes therapeutic intervention.
Ischaemic heart disease
Indicated:
Chest pain with haemodynamic instability;
New murmur following acute or recent MI;
Patient's on the Acute Coronary Syndrome pathway.
Not Indicated:
Evaluation of non-cardiac chest pain;
Patients with known ischaemic heart disease with no changes in their clinical status and have had an echocardiogram in the last 12 months.
Heart failure
Indicated:
Suspected new onset heart failure supported by clinical findings (Abnormal CXR, raised BNP, abnormal ECG);
A patient with proven heart failure (by echocardiogram) in which findings are going to change clinical decision making (have not had an echocardiogram in the last 12 months).
Not Indicated:
Minor radiographic cardiomegaly in the absence of symptoms or signs of heart failure;
Routine repeat assessment in clinically stable patients;
Assessment of patients with oedema, normal venous pressure and no evidence of cardiac disease.
Pericardial disease
Indicated:
Suspicion of pericarditis, pericardial effusion, tamponade or constriction;
Periodic assessment of moderate to large pericardial effusions;
Small pericardial effusion with acute change in patients' clinical status.
Not Indicated:
Repeat assessment of a small pericardial effusion with no change in patients' clinical status.
Lung disease
Indicated:
Lung disease with new acute clinical suspicion of cardiac involvement (Cor pulmonale, abnormal CXR, abnormal ECG, raised BNP);
Lung disease with known cardiac involvement with acute change in clinical status since previous echocardiogram;
Pulmonary embolism where echocardiography can guide whether thrombolysis is needed;
Suspected or established pulmonary hypertension (if previous echo is within 6 months and clinical status has changed then discuss on a case to case basis);
To distinguish between cardiac and non-cardiac dyspnoea when other clinical finding are ambiguous (Have not had an echocardiogram in the last 12 months);
A patient with known chronic lung disease with desaturation of an unknown cause (discuss with Cardiac consultant as bubble study maybe required).
Not indicated:
Patients with lung disease with no signs of cardiac involvement.
Neurological disorders
Indicated:
Acute interruption of blood to major visceral or peripheral artery;
Unexplained stroke or TIA without any evidence of any severe cerebral vascular disease or any other risk factors (have not had an echocardiogram in the last 12 months).
Not indicated:
Patient in whom echocardiography will not affect the decision of starting anticoagulation (Patients with known AF with a cerebrovascular event with no evidence of structural heart disease);
Patients with known heart disease who have had an echo in the last  months with no change in their cardiovascular clinical status.
Pre-operative patients
Indications:
Documented IHD with reduced functional capacity (<4METs and have not had an echocardiogram in the last  months);
Documented heart disease (have not had an echo in the last  months);
Asymptomatic patients whom other clinical tests suggest possible heart disease (abnormal ECG, abnormal CXR, increased BNP and have not had an echocardiogram in the last  months);
Murmur in the presence of acute cardiac/respiratory symptoms.
Not indicated:
Repeat assessment of the previous echocardiogram with no change in clinical status;
Routine pre-op echocardiograms.
Arrhythmia
Indicated:
Clinical suspicion of structural heart disease in a proven arrhythmia (have not had an echocardiogram in the last  months);
Assessment of LV function from primary prevention of SCD post MI;
Syncopy in a patient with clinical evidence of heart disease (have not had an echo in the last 12 months).
Not indicated:
Palpitations without any proof of arrhythmia or clinical evidence of structural heart disease;
Neurocardiogenic syncopy.
Requests for ‘Query endocarditis'

Endocarditis is suspected very frequently, but the yield from echocardiography in such patients is very low. Requests should meet at least 3 of the criteria below. It is not necessary to wait for the results of echocardiography before referring such a patient to the cardiology department if the clinical suspicion of endocarditis is high. All patients with suspected endocarditis in the context of prosthetic heart valves or implantable devices such as pacemakers should be referred to cardiology.
8.15.1 Criteria
Positive blood culture with an organism consistent with endocarditis (refer to point 8.15.2);
Raised CRP;
Pyrexia;
New murmur.

If the criteria are not met, the request will be rejected unless the request includes the name of a consultant cardiologist, consultant in infectious diseases, or consultant microbiologist who has authorised the request.

Note: During or following an episode of endocarditis, vegetation's do not necessarily resolve, irrespective of whether treatment has been successful or not, repeat echocardiography simply to ‘follow up vegetation's' are NOT indicated.
8.14.2 Organisms consistent with Endocarditis

table_items.text: note that while Staph Aureus is a cause of endocarditis, the majority of Staph Aureus bacteraemias are not caused by endocarditis by endocarditis, and so a lower index of suspicion is appropriate
compared to other organisms such as Viridans strep particularly where there is an alternative source of sepsis such as a line infection of a diabetic foot ulcer
Includes P. mutans, S. mitis, S. sanguinus, anginosus, S. oralis and S. salivarius

Organisms in this category include a number a gram-negative bacilli: Haemophilus aphrophilus (subsequently called Aggregatibacter aphrophilus and Aggregatibacter paraphrophilus); Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans (subsequently called Aggregatibacter actinomycetecomitans); Cardiobacterium hominis; Eikenella corrodens; and kingella kingae.

data.text: Note that the spectrum of organisms that cause endocarditis on prosthetic valves early after surgery (up to 1 year) is different, including a high proportion of staph epidermidis, staph aureus, and fungi. Causes of late prosthetic endocarditis (>1 year after surgery) are similar to those that cause endocarditis on native valves.
Outpatient Echocardiogram Triage

Grade 1-Urgent Outpatient Appointment (Inpatient Grade 2 echo if admitted) A condition for which there is evidence and/or agreement that echocardiography is useful and effective. All IPE requests and urgent OPE requests should fall into this class or have Consultant Cardiologist approval.
Grade 2-Routine Outpatient Appointment. Conditions for which there is conflicting evidence and/or opinion on the usefulness of echocardiography.

Grade 3-No Appointment. A condition for which there is evidence and/or agreement that echocardiography is not useful or effective. Any referral falling in to this class will not be offered an appointment unless approved by a Consultant Cardiologist. The referral form will be returned to the referring clinician and it will then be their responsibility to discuss it further with cardiology if required.
Accepted Grade 1 Outpatient Echocardiogram requests
Heart Murmurs
A murmur in a patient with cardiorespiratory symptoms;
A murmur, asymptomatic patient, clinical features indicate moderate probability of structural heart disease.
Valve Stenosis/Regurgitation
Initial diagnosis / assessment of haemodynamic severity;
Known valve disease with changing symptoms;
Revaluation of asymptomatic patients with severe valve disease;
Stenosis/Regurgitation with Pregnancy;
Periodic assessment of asymptomatic moderate stenosis/moderate regurgitation to assess LV;
Assessment pre-procedural decision making.
Infective Endocarditis
Detection and characterization of valve lesions (murmur) with clinical proven or suspected endocarditis;
Two sets of positive blood cultures.
Prosthetic Valves
Post intervention baseline studies;
Reevaluation of patients with valve replacement with changing clinical signs and symptoms.
Chest Pain
Clinical evidence of valve, pericardial, or primary myocardial disease.
Acute Myocardial Ischaemia
Measurement of baseline LV function;
Assessment of infarct size;
Evaluation of LV function prior to intervention/further therapy e.g. ICD/CRT.
Cardiomyopathy
Assessment of LV size and function.
Dyspnoea
Not indicated alone for urgent outpatient echo.
Oedema
Recent onset/new oedema with clinical evidence of cardiac disease.
Pericardial Disease
Patients with suspected pericardial disease;
Patients with suspected bleeding in the pericardial space.
Cardiac Masses and Tumours
Evaluation of patients with suspected underlying cardiac mass.
Suspected Thoracic Aortic Disease
Aortic aneurysm / dissection;
Marfan's syndrome or other connective tissue syndromes.
Pulmonary Disease
New suspected pulmonary hypertension with clinical suspicion of cardiac involvement.
Hypertension
Assessment of LV function or hypertrophy to guide clinical decision making;
Evaluation of clinically suspected aortic coarctation.
Neurological Events
Younger patients (typically <55 years) with cerebrovascular events;
Patients for whom a clinical therapeutic decision (anticoagulation, etc) will depend on the results.
Arrhythmias and Palpitations (Including Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter, AF)
Arrhythmias with clinical suspicion of structural heart disease in proven arrhythmia;
Family history of a genetic cardiac lesion associated with arrhythmia.
Syncope
Syncope in a patient with clinically suspected heart disease.
Screening for Cardiovascular
Patients and relatives with a family history of genetically transmitted cardiovascular disease;
Cardiotoxic Chemotherapy patients.
Critically Ill
The haemodynamically unstable patient.
Critically Injured
Suspected pericardial effusion or tamponade.
Adult Congenital Heart Disease
Clinically suspected congenital heart disease.
Pre-Cardioversion
Guidance for decision to attempt cardioversion e.g. LV function/MV disease;
Cardioversion for atrial flutter.
Pre-operative for elective/semi-urgent surgery
Documented IHD with reduced functional capacity;
Unexplained SOB in absence of clinical signs of heart failure;
Murmur, asymptomatic individual, clinical features suggestive severe structural heart disease.
Accepted Grade 2 Outpatient Echocardiogram Requests
Evaluation of Heart Murmurs
Asymptomatic patient with low probability of heart disease. Diagnosis of heart disease cannot be reasonably excluded by standard clinical evaluation.
Valve Stenosis/Regurgitation
Reevaluation of patients with LV dysfunction or hypertrophy.
Infective Endocarditis
Evaluation of bacteremia without a known source;
Risk stratification in established endocarditis;
Baseline post treatment.
Prosthetic Valves
Routine re-evaluation study with mild to moderate ventricular dysfunction without changing clinical signs or symptoms.
Dyspnoea
Dyspnoea with clinical signs of heart disease.
Oedema
Known oedema with known cardiac disease and change in clinical signs or symptoms.
Pericardial Disease
Routine follow-up when there has been a change in clinical status.
Cardiac Masses and Tumors
Follow-up with patients on treatment.
Suspected Thoracic Aortic Disease
Follow-up/monitoring according to Consultant advice.
Pulmonary Disease
Monitoring known pulmonary hypertension with change in clinical signs and symptoms;
Known lung disease with clinical suspicion of cardiac involvement.
Hypertension
Identification of LV diastolic filling abnormalities.
Neurological Events
Patients with suspicion of embolic disease and with cerebrovascular disease of questionable significance.
Arrhythmias and Palpitations
Arrhythmias commonly associated with, but without clinical evidence of, heart disease.
Syncope
Syncope in a patient in a high-risk occupation (e.g., pilot).
Critically Injured
Follow-up study on victims of serious blunt or penetrating trauma.
Adult Congenital Heart Disease
Follow-up annually or biannually.
Non-compliant Requests
All requests will be screened for compliance with the indications listed in sections 8-
Non-compliant requests will be rejected and the requesting Doctor informed.

In instances where a request does not comply with the indications listed in sections 8- 11 but an echocardiogram is still required by the requesting Doctor the request should be discussed with a Senior Echocardiographer who may forward it onto the Cardiology Consultants. An individual assessment may be made.
Audits

All requests will be audited for compliance with this policy. Any inappropriate requests will be labelled ‘not indicated' and returned to the requesting Doctor/ward. A record of any such requests will be logged in the Cardiac Department.
Breaches
In the event of any breaches of this procedure that lead to patient harm of any kind. A risk event form must be completed.
References
ACCF/ASE/AHA/ASNC/HFSA/HRS/SCAI/SCCM/SCCT/SCMR.( 2011). Appropriate Use Criteria for Echocardiography. Journal of American Society of Echocardiography. 24:229-67.
British Society of Echocardiography (2014) Clinical Indications for Echocardiography http://bsecho.azurewebsites.net/media/64844/indications_for_echocardiography.pdf
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2010) Chest pain of recent onset: Assessment and diagnosis. Clinical Guideline (CG 95). London: NICE.
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2014) Atrial Fibrillation: management. Clinical Guideline (CG 180). London: NICE.
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2014) Acute heart failure: diagnosis and management. Clinical Guideline (CG 187). London: NICE.
